title: England cannot make the 'Paul Scholes mistake' with Harry Winks
text:
The under-appreciation of Paul Scholes remains one of the most perplexing conundrums in English football.

A supremely gifted footballer who had a smattering of everything - yet was shunted around the England team like a rag doll to accommodate others. He’s appreciated now he’s retired, of course.

You don’t know what you’ve got until it’s gone, and all that. We may never see the likes of Scholes again - a player with radar-like passing accuracy and a dogged tenacity to boot.

The under-appreciation of Paul Scholes remains one of the most perplexing in football

Yet it seems we are in danger of falling into the same trap with Harry Winks. Unassuming and quiet, the Tottenham midfielder is similar to Scholes in terms of his personal demeanour.

They’re not too dissimilar on the pitch either. Winks - as he displayed against Bulgaria on Monday night - can dictate a football match much like Scholes was able to. The variation in his passing, too, carries similarities to Scholes.

Of course, Winks has a mightily long way to go before he can authentically be compared to the Manchester United legend. But at 23-years-old, he has time on his side.

Harry Winks has a long way to go to be seen in the same light as Scholes, but has parallels

His ability to control his team’s tempo at club and international level, though, certainly bodes well. Unfortunately, a string of England managers didn’t see the value of building their team around Scholes.

He was often moved around the pitch in hope of solving the Steven Gerrard/Frank Lampard conundrum, when really the team should really have been built around Scholes.

While Zinedine Zidane, Xavi and Thierry Henry were marvelling at Scholes from afar, English football didn’t know how to use him. Let’s hope we’re not saying the same thing about Winks 15 years down the line.

His controlled performance if Sofia, amid all the sickening racial hatred that was going on around him, displayed maturity beyond his years as he provided a technical solidity to England’s midfield base that appeared lacking in last month’s victory over Kosovo and last Friday’s defeat to the Czech Republic.

His performance against Bulgaria should at least keep him in the England team for next month’s clash against Montenegro, particularly with Jordan Henderson suspended.

Gareth Southgate certainly appreciates the calmness Winks brings to his team, his decision to restore the Spurs star to his midfield against the Bulgarians proving fruitful dividends as England romped home 6-0 victors.

Scholes was revered at Man United but was never used in the same way for the Three Lions

Likewise, his international team-mates felt Winks’ re-introduction into the starting XI and their convincing win and performance weren’t coincidental.

In Winks we have a gem; the sort of player that’s lauded on the continent but often undervalued here because of a perceived lack of physicality, although his defensive awareness and reading of the game should also be noted.

English football’s most recent remit has been to hone players who rely on their technical craft rather than their physical attributes - much like the great Spain team that had diminutive pair Xavi and Anders Iniesta orchestrating the team from midfield.

Or like Scholes did for Sir Alex Ferguson for so many years. In Winks, English football has a player who can play that role.

Let’s not undervalue him like we did with Scholes.
description: The under-appreciation of Paul Scholes remains one of the most perplexing conundrums in English football. Now, history looks as though it could well be repeating itself with Harry Winks in the midfield.
